results.title: Out of Control
results.brief_description: Developed in co-operation with the Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Unit of the Prince of Wales Hospital, this video shows how to offer support to young children between the ages of 10-14 years, to say “No” to drugs that may be offered to them. It is suitable for use by parents, community organisations, church groups, counsellors and teachers.

results.title: Swords and ploughshares
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
EPISODE 2 OF OUT OF THE FIERY FURNACE - Iron became a universal replacement for bronce; techniques evolved to “steel”, quench and temper it. The Bronze Age collapsed when a new metal “iron” emerged. The Chinese who were the first to cast it, developed huge blast furnaces. The Hittites, of Turkey, were the first to make iron of good quality, and the iron age spread from Damascus throughout Europe. Shows the importance of mining to the ancient civilizations of Grece and Rome. Presented by Michael Charlton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films

results.title: Out on a limb
results.creator_credit: Erik Roberts, Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Canadian independent filmmaker and animator Caroline Leaf is most recognised for the animated shorts she created for the National Film Board of Canada. To make her films she prefers alternative methods to the traditional “cell” animation, which she feels is devoid of emotion. “Out on a Limb” is a compilation of her works. In “The Owl Who Married a Goose” (producer, Pierre Moretti) she uses sand to create the the image. With “Entre Deaux Soeurs/Between Two Sisters” (producers, Robert Forget and Yves Leduc)she scratches emulsion from the film stock. In “The Street” (producer, Caroline Leaf), Leaf utilises waterbased tempera colours mixed with oil on milkglass as a medium. Her other films include “The Interview” (producer, David Verall), “I Met a Man” (producer, Caroline Leaf), “The Metamorphosis of Mr Samsa” (producer, Caroline Leaf) and “Hand Crafted Cinema” (producer and director, Erik Roberts), which is a filmed workshop where she talks about her work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Erik Roberts, Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Out of the past = Build my gallows high
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tourneur, Warren B. Duff and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: At the centre is the noir theme of a man’s destructive obsession with a femme fatale. The possibility of redemption is offered by the presence in a pastoral retreat of the safe, undemanding woman. The film’s special hallucinatory quality has its bases in Mitchum’s restrained playing and narration as the fated hero. Tourneur brings a downbeat, tragic other-worldliness to the complex flashback structure in which the past gradually overtakes the present. Photographer Nicholas Musuraca makes disconcerting use of deep shadow. Cast includes Robert Mitchum, Jane Greer, Kirk Douglas, Rhonda Fleming and Richard Webb. Based on the novel “Build my gallows high” by Geoffrey Homes.

results.title: Out of the blue
results.creator_credit: Leigh Jason, Isadore G. Goldsmith, Pathe Industries and Eagle-Lion
results.brief_description: Hen pecked Arthur Earthliegh (George Brent) has a respite from one woman - his wife, only to end up in the arms of another, the drunken yet voracious Olive (Ann Dvorak) who accompanies him home one night. Unbeknownst to Arthur, Olive has a heart condition and Arthur, thinking he has killed her, places the body on the next door neighbour’s patio - all under the watchful eye of 2 elderly female residents who alert the police. By the time the police have arrived, next door neighbour David has decided to extort Earthliegh into helping him dispose of the body in exchange for Earthliegh dropping the case against having David and his dog, Rabelais (who is prone to digging up the Earthliegh’s zinnias) evicted. Cast also includes Carole Landis and Turhan Bey. Based on a story by Vera Caspary.

results.title: Out of slavery: 1619-1860
results.creator_credit: Alvin Yudkoff, Milton Meltzer and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Effective use of illustrations and still photographs, coupled with powerful music, to describe the period from the beginning of the slave trade with Africa to the election of Abraham Lincoln. Deals with the role of the War of Independence and the Declaration of Independence in the abolition of slavery. Also the growth of the southern cotton industry, underground railway, and northern abolitionists. Narrated by James Earl Jones. Suitable for upper primary and secondary school levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alvin Yudkoff, Milton Meltzer and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Out of Sight Out of Mind [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: David Goldie and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Part One (only) of the four-part series ‘Out of Sight, Out of Mind’.

This documentary, made for the ABC in 1987, helped to raise awareness about a much neglected section of our society. It provided extensive insight into the prison system, interviewing prisoners, prison officers and administrators.

The full work has four parts titled ‘Locked Up’, ‘Surviving in the Nick’, ‘The Keepers and the Kept’, and ‘The Cycle of Crime’. This program pulls no punches, describes the conditions of various correctional institutions around Australia and also offers some suggestions for improvements.
